Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2009 09:11PM terryv wrote: Hi Runnr, My doctor prescribed Provigil for me because I just don't seem to have any energy.  She prescribed 100mg, but I take only half a pill because a whole pill was keeping me up at night.  I take it as needed and it seems to give me energy for a couple of days, although sometimes it is too much and I have a hard time sleeping!!!  But for me it is better than this constant fatigue! I am currently on chemo (Navelbine) and Avastin and my doctor told me I could still take Provigil so I'm not sure which chemos you can't take it with as the other poster stated. It is expensive and my insurance company won't cover it because it is only FDA approved for shift workers, not for cancer patients!!  For me it has been worth the cost. I hope this helps.  Let me know if you have any other questions and good luck! Terry
Posts.Title: Ritlan, Provigil, etc for fatigue? Runnr terryv

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2010 08:59AM terryv wrote: Hi Kirby, I'm sorry to hear that you're in so much pain.  My feet are just starting to hurt (after 7 weeks on Abraxane).  My doctor said if it gets worse she could lower the dosage so I think it is possible that they could lower your dosage.  Check with your doctor.  I hope it gets better for you.  I am very hopeful about Abraxane!  Let me know what your doctor says. Terry
Posts.Title: Abraxane Side Effects kirby mason204

Posts.Content: terryv wrote: Hi, I have been mostly a lurker on this site for many years.  I was diagnosed stage 1 in Feb 2003 and diagnosed metastatic to the bones in June 2006.  I have been through the hormonal therapy with pretty good results.  Those therapies stopped working last year, so I have been going through the various chemos - Xeloda, then Gemzar, then Navelbine.  I had good results with navelbine and went on a chemo break over the summer.  In August I started having neck and back pain which led to discovering progression in my spine.  My latest scans showed a tiny (less than 1 cm) lesion on my liver.  This is the first involvement of my organs.  I just finished radiation and now the doctor has put me back on Navelbine.  In addition, because it is now in my liver, my doctor wants to add Avastin.  After she told me this I came home and did a little research.  One of the first things I find is an article that states that Roche has just suspended a study involving Avastin because too many patients developed congestive heart failure.  I found many other people that also said they developed heart problems and suspected Avastin.  Now I am really scared to start this drug.  My quality of life is pretty good right now and I want it to continue that way.  Does anyone have any experience with this?  Am I overreacting about this?  Thanks in advance for anything you can tell me.  Although I haven't posted much before, this board has been a huge source of knowledge and comfort for me.  Thanks to all of you for that!!! Terry Dx 6/19/2006, Stage IV, 0/7 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Worried about Avastin terryv mkl48

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2010 12:10PM terryv wrote: Dear Linda, I am so sorry that you are going through this.  I will say a prayer that the radiation will work and that in the meantime you can get some relief from this situation.  I know it's got to be hard right now, but hopefully this is just another bump in the road that you will overcome and you will be back to your active self soon. Terry

Posts.Title: Where is everyone from? shelbyjane72 BarbaraA
College funds for our children Fitztwins EnglishMajor

Posts.Content: May 31, 2010 11:43PM terryv wrote: Pee, I think you are doing great since you are able to take care of a baby all week!  You should be proud of yourself.  When I was diagnosed with mets 4 years ago I was training for a half marathon.  Now I can't even run around the block!  I have three kids - teens and preteens and I am just trying to make it to all of their activities.  In the last week  I went to my son's confirmation, his baseball game, watched my son play drums and my daughter twirl flags in the Memorial Day Parade and managed to have a party for my son's 8th grade graduation that lasted 7 hours.  Today I was so exhausted I couldn't get out of bed after the parade and had to miss our neighborhood barbeque.  My husband completely understands, but my 79 year old mother seems very put out that I can't go, go, go since she is here visiting.  She even made plans to go out to lunch tomorrow with my neighbor (who she just met) so she wouldn't be bored sitting around here all day.  I guess my feelings are a bit hurt and she is in complete denial about my disease.  I wish she could understand how I am feeling.  Sorry to go off onto my own rant!!!  I completely understand what you are feeling.  I hope it gets better!!
Posts.Title: Ability to do what you used too do. pee pee

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2009 11:18AM terryv wrote: Hi Jennifer, I am in a similar situation, but I live in Illinois.  My ex-husband is actively involved in my boys' lives, but I would still like for my boys to live with my husband when I die.  My ex just doesn't always have his priorities straight.  I have spoken to my lawyer about this and she said the courts favor the biological parent.  She had me create a will that included my wishes for the boys, but she said the courts are not bound by my wishes.  My boys are 12 and 13 right now.  I just hope I live long enough to see them through to adulthood.  I would definitely have a will drawn up that includes your wishes.  I think it is crap that our wishes aren't followed when it comes to the most important thing in our lives - our children!  I pray that we all make it until our kids make it to 18 and then it won't be an issue!  Good luck to you. Terry
Posts.Title: Single Moms - Custody after we are gone? JeninMichigan hermajesty

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2010 06:40PM terryv wrote: I had my 4 year mets anniversary in June.  I hadn't considered myself a "veteran" but I guess I am!  Thanks for this thread - I feel like I have actually accomplished something - although truly it has been all of the meds and the incredible suppport I have received!  I did hormonals for about two years and have been doing chemo for two years.  I've had my ups and downs but honestly it has been better than I thought it would be when they first diagnosed me with mets in the ER when I was in so much pain I could barely move!  I have had a pretty decent quality of life and am so thankful for that.  This board has helped quite a bit too during my dark days.  Thanks to all of you! Terry
